awd_titl_txt: CIF:Medium:Collaborative Research:An Information-theoretic approach to nanopore sequencing
awd_abstract_narration:
Fast and inexpensive DNA sequencing technology is beginning to impact society through applications ranging from personalized medicine to understanding of ecological systems enabled by second generation sequencers. Wider applicability of second-generation sequencing technology is limited, however, by the short length of the DNA fragments that can be read. Nanopore sequencing has the potential to overcome several shortcomings of state-of-the art short-read sequencing.

The goal of this project is to create new foundational theory and algorithms enabling several applications of nanopore sequencing. This research will support nanopore technology to become a leading next-generation sequencing approach. This project also contains a unique inter-university education and research program, which will include joint and collaborative student advising and curricular development.

To realize the advantages of nanopore sequencing, methods for reducing and combating sequencing errors need to be developed. In a nanopore sequencer, DNA is transmigrated through a nanopore, and the ion current variations through the pore are measured to infer the DNA sequence. The mapping from the DNA sequence to the observed current trace, has several impairments (causing errors) including multiple nucleotides affecting each observation, random variations in nanopore response, dwelling time variations, synchronization errors, and noise. This project develops a holistic approach using tools from information theory and bio-informatics based on multiple interacting thrusts: (1) developing mathematical models and (2) information theory for nanopore sequencing, (3) decoding algorithms exploiting the structure of the nanopore channel, and (4) the theory and methodology for applications in DNA forensics, DNA phasing and DNA information storage. We couple this with an existing experimental nanopore sequencing research program, guiding models and the theory/algorithms with specific data as well as validating these ideas.

por.por_cntn:
This project, which started in 2017 was motivated by the observation that fast and inexpensive sequencing technology is beginning to impact society through many applications, enabled by second- generation sequencers. However, at the beginning of this project a new sequencing technology called nanopore sequencing was started to be created. Our goal in this project was to create new foundational theory, and algorithms enabling several applications of nanopore sequencing. We believe we made significant contributions to nanopore sequencing theory as well as practice, as seen from our publications in prestigious Information Theory and Bioinformatics venues. The work also funded several phd students. The resuts were also disseminated through several invited lectures in various  academic settings by the PI.

This project developed several fundamental ideas in nanopore sequencing, which were discovered and published during the course of this project. The details are in the publications and were also summarized in annual reports of the project. Among the several works  we would like to highlight the following:
(i)  Information theoretic models and bounds for nanopore sequencing: When nanopore sequencers were being deployed at the beginning of the project, there was no precise mathematical model and theoretical bounds for its performance.  We proposed a mathematical model for the ``channel'' from the input DNA sequence to the observed current, and calculated bounds on the information extraction capacity of the nanopore sequencer (published IEEE Trans. Inf. Theory, 2018). This also gave us insights into the error patterns induced by the physics of the nanopore and we extensively used this insight into the algorithms we developed for nanopore sequencing alignments and discovering structural variants.  (ii) QAlign: Alignment and assembly of DNA sequences from nanopores: We used the model and insights from our signal-level mathematical models for the nanopore channel, to develop new alignment schemes for nanopore readers. The high error rate of nanopore readers makes accurate and efficient alignment difficult; however, by understanding the error patterns through our mathematical model, we significantly improved on the state-of-the-art nanopore sequencers by demonstrating it on real data sets including human genomes (published Bioinformatics 2021). (iii) HQAlign: aligning nanopore reads for SV detection using current-level modeling: Structural variants (SVs) are block errors in the genome with significant disease implications. We used the model and insights from our models for the nanopore channel, to developed new techniques that can isolate SVs more effectively than the state-of-the-art (published Bioinformatics 2023).
